titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IX. Monday— Read by Lamp-light

Finished my version of the seventh Psalm— Elisha Turner came and brought me 75 Copies of my Oration— I had received and distributed to my friends one hundred copies before— I sent off 27 copies this day. Alpheus Spear was here— I sent him half a bushel of Solomon Thayer’s grain, weighing 16. pounds— This is all that I had raised from the two quarts which I had purchased of him two years since; and this when threshed was found swarming with worms.— It was showery with Thunder Claps the whole day.
2. IV:15 Tuesday.

Began the version of the 8th. Psalm; which I undertook in the six line Stanza; and composed two of them— Isaac H. Adams went to Boston, in the Carriage, with which John Kirk returned there; and came back in the Stage this Evening. I received this morning several Letters—from my Son John, J. Sergeant, N. Biddle, C. J. Ingersoll, and B. Pickman, to all which I am now unable to reply. And also from John Souther, Chairman of the Assessors and Selectmen, calling upon me for a Schedule of all my Estate, Real and Personal, to be answered this morning— It was impossible— I had conversed upon the subject sometime since with Souther; and intended to have prepared and sent in the Schedule; but I have been so constantly and unremittingly engaged since that time that I have not been able to do— I shall suffer for it, but cannot help it. Throughout life it has seemed to me that I could never devote intense application to one object, without neglecting others at least for the last two months I have been occupied upon objects not unworthy of one aiming at the good of his Country and his kind.— Nothing for which I ought to take to myself shame. Mr Holbrook a collector of taxes from Braintree came with two tax bills for the years 1829 and 1830 which I paid. Price Greenleaf came and budded for me a number of Apple trees in my Nursery. Woodhouse, Trowbridge, Russet, Greening from my own neighbouring grounds; and Garden red. Then, Gloria Mundi, Pennick’s Winter red, Grindstone, Philadelphia Red-streak and Spitzenburg.— Five home-bred, and five foreign, all in seedling stocks of my own raising— Most of the Stocks are mean and poor; but they are all four years old; and the shoots from the buds may improve them—
3. V. Wednesday.

Finished my version of the 8th. Psalm, and began that of the 9th. in the eight line Stanza— After finishing the 8th. I discovered that I had already made one of it in the eight line Stanza, in May last—which speaks no encomium upon my Memory— The whole day was showery with Thunder, but after dinner it appeared to clear away and I walked up and met Mr Lemuel Humphrey at the foot of Penn’s Hill.— There he measured and staked out a lot containing one third of an Acre of land adjoining the School House, and which I have agreed to sell to Joseph Crane for 400 dollars. He also measured off and laid out in lots the whole distance from the School House, to Henry Hardwick’s House, which makes eleven lots each with five Rods and one third in front and extending to a strait line across the lot in the rear— The divisions of the line in the front were marked with a paint brush, upon the Stone wall— In crossing the meadow, I found it as wet as it usually is on the opening of Spring.— I went all over Harvey Fields house, which is nearly finished— It was dark when I returned home— Mr Humphrey promised to draft, and bring me a plan of the whole front line, laid off into the eleven lots. These interruptions, and the sultry heat of the weather interrupt me much in the composition of the Eulogy, and in writing this diary.
4. V. Thursday.

I received this morning a cover from General La Fayette enclosing a printed copy of his address of 13 June last to his constituents the Electors of Meaux to whom he presents himself as a Candidate for re-election to the Legislative Assembly— A note from Levi Woodbury acknowledging the Receipt of the copy of my Oration which I addressed to him a Letter of like acknowledgement from P. S. Duponceau at Philadelphia—warm and enthusiastic, and a note from Mr Frothingham at Boston, written on Tuesday Evening, urgently inviting me to attend the Wednesday Evening club, to meet last Evening at his house— Micah Orcutt an old Soldier of this Revolution, who by the Act of Congress of 1818. had a pension of 8 dollars a Month, which in consequence of the subsequent act was revoked, came to ask charity and my Assistance to obtain restoration of the pension, which he said would suffice to make his last days comfortable— He had been to Mr Webster, Mr Gorham, Mr Appleton and General Dearborn, all of whom had assisted him, and all except Mr Gorham who is no longer in Congress, promised their aid to get him on the Pension list again. I did the same— Mr Richardson has at both the last Sessions of Congress, carried Bills for that purpose through the House of Representatives which have failed in the Senate merely for want of Time. The old man had a piteous tale of distress to tell—simple and pathetic— He told me he had been here three or four years ago, when I was President, and I had a remembrance of him but it was indistinct— Lieutt. T. B. Adams junr was here, and I dined at my brothers— On my return home after dinner, I found Mrs Lawrence of Cohasset with a Letter from Mr Richardson. She is widow of an Ensign in the Army, who was wounded at the Sortie from Fort Erie in the last War, and some years after died in consequence of the wound.— Three Bills at successive Sessions of Congress have passed the house of Representatives, to give her a pension for five years; but failed for want of time in the Senate— She seemed much distressed; and I promised her all the assistance in my power— It was but a variation of the case of the Morning.
5. IV. Friday

Solomon Thayer called here this Morning, with a Root of his singular grain— From this single root there are thirty or more spines each with as many kernels of grain at the head which is equivalent to a reproduction of 900 for one—but mine has not been equally successful— He says his grain weighs from 32: to 33 pounds a bushel which corresponds with the weight of mine; but gives it little claim to the name of wheat— He thinks it will produce at the rate of 100 bushels an Acre, and will be more than a substitute for Oats to feed horses— Captain Eliphalet Smith brought me a subscription Paper, for building a new Episcopal Church in the place of the old one in this Town which they propose to pull down.— Mr. William Apthorp offers to give them a lot of land for this purpose, on the corner of the road, diagonally from his house— On condition that they build the Church within two years— They propose to begin, if they can raise a subscription of five thousand dollars for pews not to exceed one hundred dollars each, except what may be bidden for the choice— I subscribed for one pew— The old Church is of wood, and upwards of a hundred years of age— But among the motives for building another
is the hope of disappointing the Universalists who are projecting to gather a Church, and to build a Meeting house for themselves— They have drawn off a number of the worshipers at the Episcopal Church, as well as of Mr Whitney’s flock, and will probably not be deterred from their purpose by this expedient— More than a century back there were two houses of public worship in the precinct which is now Quincy— The population was then certainly not one fifth of what it is now; and a third house of worship will doubtless form a congregation respectable for numbers— Price Greenleaf came this afternoon and budded again several of the Stocks of Apple-trees in my Nursery.— I had received the slips from Mr Brooks at Medford of the Andover, Beverley, Large sweet Autumn, Payson, Seek no further, and Washington Pearmain Apples— I planted also a Row of Huckleberries and four whole Pears, in a lower bed of the Nursery— Mr Daniel Greenleaf called and invited me to spend the Evening at his house— But Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here till past nine, and as he was engaged to go there promised to make my excuses.
6. V. Saturday.

I received Letters this morning, from John B. Hearn, of Chillicothe Ohio, requesting two Copies of my Oration of the 4th. of last Month; and one of my Address to the Citizens of Washington, delivered on the fourth of July 1821— Of the last I have none here to spare. Mr Hearn is an entire Stranger to me— From Richard Rush, William Plumer, and his Son, both of Epping New-Hampshire, acknowledging the receipt of copies of my Oration, which I had respectively sent to them. Their remarks are all highly complimentary, each according to the peculiarity of his own character.— Rush enthusiastic— Dearborn with argument confirmative— Plumer the father with moderate and cool observation; and the Son, contesting one of my positions, and taking a range upon other subjects.— Mr Rush mentions that he had definitively declined a nomination as a Candidate for the Office of President of the United States— My Nephew Lieutenant Adams was here, and Price Greenleaf came and budded a number more of seedling Apple trees, from the same Slips sent to me from Medford by Mr Brooks— I am still toiling upon the Eulogy on Mr Monroe, my plan of which forms itself as I proceed— It has assumed the shape of a Memoir upon his life— It was long, eventful, and connected with the principal events of our history from the Declaration of Independence, for a full half century— The fragment of autobiography sent me by Mr Gouverneur comes down only to the close of Mr Monroe’s first mission to France— For the narrative during the War of the Revolution I have been obliged to recur to the published collection of General Washington’s Letters—to Marshall’s life of him—to Gordon’s and Stedman’s Histories of the War, to possess myself fully of the chain of facts, and it absorbs half my time— It also convinces me that my plan is not a good one— That my narrative will be long, tedious and dull, and that I shall be compelled to abridge, without knowing exactly where—
7. IV:45. Sunday—

Heard Mr Whitney in the Morning from Matthew 12.30. “He that is not with me is against me,” and in the afternoon from Job 19.25 “For I know that my Redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the Earth: 26. And though after my skin, worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shall I see God: 27. Whom I shall see for myself, and mine eyes shall behold, and not another; though my veins be consumed within me” The morning discourse, was
occasional upon the Communion which was administered immediately after it. Louisa C. Smith and my brother’s Son Joseph dined with us— Mr Whitney’s commentary upon his afternoon text was not very satisfactory— The meaning of the text itself is obscure and uncertain— It forms part of the funeral Service of the Episcopal Church, and has been considered as not only asserting the doctrine of the immortality of the Soul, but as prophetically referring to Jesus Christ the redeemer of the world, at least fifteen hundred years before he was born in the body.— Mr Whitney does not understand the passage in this Sense— The English Translation to make out an intelligible meaning to the passage has added some very emphatical but questionable words— The Book of Job has been ascribed to Moses and Ezekiel, who lived at a distance of at least seven hundred years from each other. In the Book of Ezekiel Job is named—but in that of Job there is not the most distant allusion to any portion of the Hebrew History or Scriptures— Satan figures in it indeed, and he was a historical Hebrew character— But he is presented in Job, as holding in his rebellious State an intercourse rather more familiar with the Creator, than comports with the sentence to which he was doomed at the fall— The rebellion of the Angels which preceded the Creation of Man is but obscurely alluded to in the Scriptures— I heard the late Dr Gardiner once preach a Sermon in which he said that Satan was a mysterious personage often mentioned in the sacred Books— I walked this Evening to my brothers and on returning home found John Kirk had come out from Boston, with the Carriage—
8. IV. Monday.—

Finished the version of the 9th. Psalm yesterday— Began the 10th this Morning. A pamphlet was left at my house this Morning; and a Letter signed James Shedel—with a message that the writer would call in the course of the day— The Letter was an argument threatening and persuading me to pay for suppressing the pamphlet— I went to Boston, and attended the Meeting of the Committee of the ΦΒ.Κ Society which sat from 10 till past 2. Judge Story the Chairman had a Report prepared which was earnestly and warmly debated for four hours— It was in substance a new Constitution for the Society, making several essential changes in its Laws; of which the abolition of all Secrets and promises was one— I was desirous that the alteration should be confined to this and to one other By-Law which subjected the members of the graduating Class to all the expenses of the Anniversary Celebration— There was no direct opposition to the Articles of the Report abolishing Secrets and Promises, except from Colonel Baldwin, who said he wished for no change, and preferred that the Society should continue as it was, but used no argument— All the other Articles of the Report were carried by bare majorities— I strongly opposed the Article for altering the mode of Election.— It has always hitherto required, an unanimous vote— The change proposed is, that a vote of two thirds of the voters present shall be sufficient for admission. Edward Everett the President, and Judge Story are both exceedingly bent upon effecting this alteration, and have been labouring to accomplish it for eight or ten years— I think it will change entirely the character of the Society and make it less select—for one improper exclusion which it will prevent, it will secure the admission of ten pale-coloured candidates of little or no value to Literature or to the reputation of the Society— Judge Story, argued the point with great earnestness; and carried the Article by a bare majority, seven members only of the Committee being present The
Judge was called out for an hour to attend a Garden and Cemetery Meeting, and placed me in the Chair during his absence. While he was gone, one Article of his Report was set aside, and to the rest excepting that which I opposed there was little or no objection— But the judge was a little discomposed at the loss even of one Article of his Report, which he considered as forming one entire and perfect system, the symmetry of which would be lost by the omission of any part of it— He asked for a reconsideration of the vote, by which the Article had been rejected, and Dr Lowell moved the reconsideration— But two members of the Committee had withdrawn since the vote had been taken, and upon my adverting to the usual rule of deliberative assemblies that decided questions shall not be reconsidered by smaller numbers than when the vote was taken, had been present, the Judge gave up the point. He had now two Volumes of the Records of the Society which had not been produced at the meeting of the Society or at the former meeting of the Committee— By these it appears that in 1806. the Oath had been abolished, and the solemn promise of secrecy substituted in its place—and that the promise of assisting a brother with Life and fortune had been discarded— And that in 1825. an entire new System of Laws had been adopted—compiled by Edward Everett— The Report of Judge Story confirmed the whole of this Code, with two or three exceptions; and I objected that although I was not aware of any change which I should wish to be made in the existing Laws, yet I was equally unprepared to report a confirmation of what I had not read; and exceptions for which I did not see the necessity— Every vote was however carried against me, and even Coll. Baldwin, who was averse to any alteration voted for the Support and every Article of it—to avail himself of the objections against every Article, and thereby secure if possible against the whole a vote of rejection— Judge Jackson did much the same, though he said not one word, against the Article to abolish the Secrets and Promises— I asked judge Story for a copy of those two Articles, which he gave me, and I told him that when the Report should be made, I should move to lay it on the table, and take up those Articles alone— And I said my object would be to limit the discussion to them fearing that by scattering it over several other objects, the Sense of the Society upon that could not be obtained— He said that nothing would be done. That there was a great diversity of opinion among the members, upon the abolition of the Secrets; and that there was an opposition organizing against the whole measure— The judge said that the members elect of the Class now commencing Seniors at the University had declined accepting the membership, burdened as it now is with a tax of fifteen dollars each on admission, to defray the expenses of the anniversary.— The Report proposes to discard the Medal and Ribbons, and that the expenses shall be defrayed; as the Society may from time to time direct— I suggested the expediency of retrenching many of the expenses; such as the band of Music—and even the dinner— The Consideration of this was postponed— When the Article for changing the mode of election was apparently about to pass, I moved as an amendment to it that every thing having reference to friendship, as being one of the objects of the Institution, should be expunged—leaving it a mere literary Society— This struck them disagreeably; and I assured them I proposed it only as what appeared to me a consistent consequence following from the change in the mode of election— A Society of Friends should admit no new member but with the unanimous consent of all the old— A Society merely literary may exist without any other link of Association— The Report however was adopted, and is to be made to the Society at their adjourned Meeting next Thursday— I dined at Charles’s house, and Mr Peter C. Brooks was there— In the Evening Mrs Adams came home with me to Quincy.
On my arrival at home about Sunset I found there a man who said his name was Joshua Colburn— That he had been a Scholar at Harvard University, but was now a Clerk in a Counting House— He had been sitting waiting for me from three O’Clock in the afternoon— He said he had accidentally gone into a Printing Office, where he had seen a pamphlet which he thought calculated to do very great injury to me—and he had urged the printer not to publish it— That he was himself a warm friend to me and my character. That it was known, from Maine from New-Hampshire and other States, that it was expected I should be nominated by the Anti-Masonic Convention, to be held next Month at Baltimore, for election to the Presidency of the United States— That the Masons knew of this pamphlet and would circulate immense numbers of them— That many thousands of them were ordered from New-York, Philadelphia, and the Southern and Western States. That the Printer was a poor man, and said he did not want to hurt me, but that printing was his profession and he must live by it— That David Henshaw, the Collector at Boston; and Nat Green the Postmaster had ordered great numbers of the pamphlet and the Jackson-men and Masons would circulate it all over the Country. I asked him who had printed the pamphlet he said Joseph Homer— I asked whether he was of the firm of Beals and Homer: he said, No—but they would support him in issuing the publication— I asked him who had informed him that Henshaw and Greene had bespoken so many of the pamphlet. He said Mr Doolittle— I asked him how it was expected to suppress a pamphlet of which so many copies had been ordered from all parts of the Country— He said the copy right would be worth about five thousand dollars. But that the Edition that had been printed would not cost so much— That not one copy of it had gone out of the Printers hands; and he was willing to sell the whole of it— I told him the Printer had deceived him, if he had told him, that not one copy of it had gone out of his hands—for I had a copy of it myself— I believed the pamphlet was full of falsehoods—but if events in which I had no part, and over which I could have no controul were to injure my character, I could not help it— If the Jackson men and Masons were apprehensive that I should be nominated by the Anti-Masonic Convention at Baltimore, they might set themselves at ease— I had no reason to believe that any of the Antimasons had such intention, but directly the reverse, I had— But however that might be, I would not give one dollar to suppress any thing that any human being can publish of me, true or false— Mr Colburn then took his leave and went away. Henshaw and Green are at the bottom of this as they were of the Cunningham Correspondence— Their sting is now invenomed by the fear of losing their places.— There is also Masonic Charity in the Cup—
9. V. Tuesday.

Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston came about 9 O’Clock this morning and we were occupied all the forenoon, in examining the Account which Mr Curtis had prepared for Settlement at the Probate office, and in conferring upon the management of the Estate. I had received a Letter from Horace Gray, proposing to purchase or to rent for years the lot of Land belonging to Mr Boylston’s Estate at Charlestown.— Mr Curtis said that Mr Devens an Inhabitant of Charlestown who owns land adjoining upon it, had also applied to know the price of which it was to be sold.
There are about 16000 feet of the lot, and at the appraisement of the Estate, it was valued at 4000 dollars for the whole or 25 Cents a square foot.— It would not have brought that price at the time; but Mr Curtis says it would now readily sell at 35 cents a foot— The reason of this appretiation is that it is believed the projected Railway from Lowell must come to Horace Gray’s wharf at the deepest water and safest mooring ground of Boston Harbour, and this Land adjoining upon it is the best in that neighbourhood for the erection of warehouses upon it.— If the Railway should come there, Mr Curtis thinks it will enhance very greatly the value of this lot— As we are under no necessity of selling it immediately we all thought it most advisable to reserve for the benefit of the Estate, the chances of its rising value and with the concurrence both of Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston, I answered Mr Gray, that our price for the land would be at the rate of a dollar a foot, and that if he preferred renting it we would name a price if he would inform us for a term of how many years he wished to take it— As it was apparent that Mr Gray would decline any further Treaty upon the subject we agreed to ask the same price of Mr Devens, and keep the land for the chances of future Appretiation— About Noon we went to the Probate Court, where the judge in a very few minutes received and swore us to the account which he immediately passed— We confirmed the Sales of two of the Lots at Princetown— And I agreed with Mrs Boylston that I would go with my ward, Ward Nicholas Boylston, to Cambridge on the day of his Examination for admission at the University which will be the Friday after Commencement— Ward has an excellent Certificate from his Preceptor— But Thomas has no disposition for study, and Mrs Boylston wishes that he may not be sent to College— I promised to enquire of President Quincy with regard to the best arrangements for board and lodging at Cambridge for the entering Student— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston dined with us, and left us soon after dinner to return to Roxbury— Alpheus Spear came with a written paper concerning the fencing of Rocky Island at the Mount Wollaston farm which I put in shape to be recorded on the Town’s Books.— Mr Humphrey the Surveyor, brought me a plan of my School-house lot, at the foot of Penn’s Hill laid out in house lots, as we had measured it upon the ground— Lieutenant T. B. Adams junr. was here, returned from his excursion to the State of New-York.
10. V. Wednesday.

Mr Curtis and Dr Phipps called this morning to consult with me concerning two Letters which they had received from the Publishers of my Oration, in Boston— The Copy Right was taken out in the name of Messrs. Phipps, Curtis and Seaver, and the publishers agreed to pay them a certain graduated per-centage upon the numbers sold— The Editors of the National Intelligencer of the New-York Spectator and Commercial Advertiser have published the whole Oration, and the Boston publishers suggest the enquiry whether suits should not be brought against them, for violation of the copy-right— I said there could be no doubt that the publication was a breach of copy right, by the Editors of the Newspapers, but whether in such a case a Jury would give in damages a sum sufficient to pay the costs of the suit might be doubted—Fourth of July Orations were generally considered, as public property, and copy-rights of them had seldom been taken out— I had besides understood Mr Lord, that he had sent Copies to several publishers of Newspapers with express permission to publish from them any extracts they pleased— These permissions
might be produced against him, even by others than those to whom they had been granted, at least in mitigation of damages—and it was very doubtful, whether the damages recovered would be sufficient to pay the costs and charges of a suit— I thought the best course for the Printers would be, to write to the Editors of Newspapers who have published the whole Oration, complaining of the breach of Copy right, as to professional brothers and asking them some compensation for the injury— They concluded to give— Price Greenleaf was here this afternoon, and budded several Sucker Stock Pear-trees in my Garden, with Harvard, Napoleon andPear buds— His father Mr Thomas Greenleaf called in the Evening, and took my acknowledgment, and my wife’s of the Deed of 1/3 of an Acre of Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill to Joseph Crane— I planted in the Nursery one Row, of Nursery red Apple Seeds.
11. IV. Thursday. Sun rose 5.2.

I went in to Boston early this Morning, and immediately attended the Meeting of the Φ.Β.K. Society. In the morning it was held in the Hall of the American Academy in State Street. I met in the Room below Judge Story, the Chairman of the Committee who had a short Article prepared for his Report, in place of that which was rejected in Committee on Monday; and who seemed to think it absolutely necessary, to make the Report itself entire I agreed that he should Report it— Mr Edward Everett the President immediately called the Meeting to order. The Report was read, upon which Mr Everett requested Mr S. C. Phillips of Salem to take the Chair, in Committee of the whole— I then immediately moved that the Report of the Committee should be laid on the Table to take up two Resolutions which I offered; which were to remove all injunction of Secresy, by the Society upon any present member; and no secret of any kind should ever be imposed, or promise exacted from any member to be admitted hereafter— There arose immediately questions of order, whether this motion could be received in Committee of the whole and I finally varied it by moving to amend the Report, by striking it all out, except the introductory words, and to insert my two Resolutions in the place— This brought on the whole discussion. I assigned my Reasons for my Motion—which were, first that I thought no other alteration of the Constitution and Laws of the Society necessary, but the abolition of Secrets and promises— Secondly that I disapproved all the other alterations proposed in the Report, and thirdly that I wished to keep the discussion confined to those objects alone; apprehending that if the whole Report should be debated it would be only a waste of time and that nothing would eventually be done. There was much discussion upon forms; and finally the Committee rose and reported that they had come to no Resolution— The President resumed the Chair with a general assent that he should without leaving it again, be at Liberty to enter into the debate— I renewed my proposition to strike out and amend the Report, which Judge Story, Edward Everett and S.C. Phillips opposed— I was not sustained by any one— At last Theophilus Parsons, moved that the whole subject should be indefinitely postponed, and made a Speech to sustain his motion somewhat rude and personal upon me— He said it would be remembered, that at the former meeting of the Society, I had made the same motion which I had now repeated and that after a full and thorough discussion of the subject my motion had received the solitary vote of the mover— That a respectable Committee had been raised to make Report at this Meeting. They had now reported, and the first thing I did was to renew the very same motion,
which had already been unanimously rejected— This he thought would be highly disrespectful to the Committee— That the Reason I had assigned for the abolition of Secresy was only that there happened to be at this time a popular excitement against it; which he thought was the very reason for retaining it— Alexander H. Everett then rose to speak, and an objection was made that upon a motion of indefinite postponement there could be no debate— He persisted however, and with much opposition observed that Parsons had made a motion, said to admit of no debate, but was allowed to make a Speech with it, not only debateable, but departing from the subject to cast personal reflections upon me.— He was there allowed to proceed so far as to say, there was nothing disrespectful in proposing a substitute for the Report of a Committee— Parsons was now silenced; and after much debate my proposition was rejected, and the Report was again taken up— It was near two O’Clock. Parsons crossed the room, and whispered to Judge Jackson, who shortly after renewed the Motion for an indefinite postponement of the whole subject; and again sustained his motion by a Speech which could not be answered, because the motion admitted of no debate— Of this I complained, and with the assent of judge Jackson was allowed to answer his argument; which was that the Secrets of the Society ought not to be removed, because it would be yielding to a more momentary popular clamour— That there was nothing worth retaining in the Secrets themselves, but that to abolish them in deference to an artificial excitement got up among the People, was unworthy of the Society— I answered in substances first disclaiming all intention of disrespect to the Committee, and taking no other notice whatever of Parsons’s Speech— I then replied to judge Jackson, that the excitement to which he had alluded was the very reason why I earnestly desired the abolition of the Secrets—to relieve the Society from the Odium of holding them.— I considered the excitement prevailing in the public mind on this subject just, and well founded— I believed it would increase and prevail more and more—that if we disregard it now, it will press upon us again till we shall be obliged to do upon compulsion that which would now be voluntary. I observed that Judge Jackson had voted in Committee for the whole Report, and for these Articles particularly; he approved then of the Abolition of Secresy— He thought it right. he agreed with the principle upon which the public feeling was excited, but because a large portion of the People in addition to this sense of right, had a deep anxious and earnest feeling on the same side, he was now for setting both the feeling and the right at defiance—he would reject that which he approved, because it was intensely desired by multitudes who approved it also. This was a process of logic widely different from that which was natural to the judge’s mind, and to which I hoped he would not upon full consideration adhere— He replied that he had indeed agreed to the whole Report, but this was the Article that he liked least in it; or rather he disliked it— Judge Story spoke also very earnestly against the postponement, and the vote was of more than two to one against it— The meeting there adjourned to meet at four in the afternoon at the Athenaeum Lecture room— Timothy Fuller told me I had Jonathan-Russell’d Judge Jackson, but I doubt whether I should have carried the vote against him; if Judge Story had not on this question been with me. On leaving the Hall I met Alderman R. D. Harris whom I informed that I should be ready to deliver the Eulogy on Mr Monroe, either the 24th. or 25th. of this Month— He said the examination of the Public Schools would be on the 24th— That my day might be either the 23d. or the 25th: I told him either would suit me. He promised to consult the Council, and let me know the result— I asked him where they proposed it should be— He said they had first thought of Faneuil Hall; but as that place was not favourable for the Voice, they now
probably would chuse the Old South Church, which I told him would suit me better than Faneuil Hall— I asked him if they intended to have any religious Solemnities— He said perhaps a Prayer, by the eldest Clergyman in the City— I said that Mr. Monroe having been of the Episcopal Church it might perhaps be proper to have parts of their funeral Service read— To which he said he would attend— I next met Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and told him Mr Horace Gray had answered our Letter relating to the Land at Charlestown, as I had expected declining further Treaty— He said Patrick Jackson, of the Lowell Railway Company had just applied to him for the same Land, and we agreed to give him the same answer as we gave to Gray. DeGrand walked with me to my Son Charles’s house and left me at the door— I dined there and at 4 P.M. attended the adjourned meeting of the ΦΒ.Κ at the Athenaeum Lecture Room— The Report of the Committee was taken up and debated Article by Article— The Articles for all secresy in future were not contested— James T. Austin proposed an addition removing all injunction of Secresy upon present members which was adopted— The main debate was upon the change in the mode of election from an unanimous vote to two thirds— I opposed the change with great earnestness— Judge Story, and Edward Everett supported it with equal fervour— The judge in a long Speech— Coll. Baldwin made a few remarks against the change, and moved to strike out the Article from the Report. No other member supported me, and James Savage, who had not attended any of the other Meetings was there and replied to me in aid of Story and Everett— Mr Gould moved that the proportion of votes for election should be nine tenths but that was rejected— It was drawing towards Sunset when the vote was taken and was a tie 32 and 32. which Everett the President decided was a vote against striking out: though I claimed that it was a vote against the Article which ought not to be adopted but by a positive majority and referred to the practice of the Old Congress where the question upon words moved to be stricken out, always was, shall the words stand and a positive majority was required, or they were stricken out. The vote however was taken upon each Article separately; and on coming to that Dr Lowell moved that the proportion of two thirds should be struck out, and three fourths inserted, which prevailed and then the Article was adopted by a very small majority. All the remainder of the Report was accepted; and a vote passed that the expenses of this years anniversary celebration, should be paid from the fund of the Society, with a small assessment upon the class now to be graduated—the meeting closed after Sunset, and I then immediately returned to Quincy— I received this Morning a note from Mr Madison acknowledging the receipt of the copy which I had sent him of my 4th. of July Oration— His Seat was the initials of his name and the Motto Veritas, non verba magistri.
12. IV. Friday.

George Veazie was here and I settled with him a bill now shingling my two barns adjoining my dwelling house— Price Greenleaf was here, and put some buds of Pear trees, into growing Stocks from Suckers.— I planted a row of Nursery red apple-seeds in the third bed on the western side of the newly reclaimed ground in my Nursery— Some weeks since, I received a Letter from E. S. Davis, at Abbeville, South-Carolina, mentioning that he was compiling a comparative view of the Constitutions of the United States, and asking of me a copy of the Constitution of Massachusetts as amended, and a list of the
Governors of the Colony from its first Settlement, and of the State since the Declaration of Independence— I answered his Letter this day; and sent him the List of Governors, as requested, and a printed copy of the Constitution and Amendments, excepting that recently adopted, changing the time of commencing the political year, from the last week in May to the first week in January—and reducing the ordinary annual Sessions of the Legislature from two to one— I finished the versions of the tenth Psalm.
13. IV. Saturday. Birth of a daughter to my Son Charles.

Began my version of the 11th. Psalm—and I am deeply engaged in the composition of the Eulogy upon James Monroe. My wife went immediately after dinner, to Boston, intending to be with my Son Charles’s wife at the time of her confinement— Edward Everett came out this afternoon with Mr Chandler, now the Editor of the United States Gazette at Philadelphia. Much conversation upon the political topics of the day; he brought me Letters from J. Connell, and Josiah Randall, and told me that Edward Ingersoll was the author, of the numbers in the United States Gazette signed X. Y. upon Louis M’Lane’s arrangement with the British Government concerning the Colonial Trade. Adam Curtis came, and took the Deed of 1/3 of an Acre of Land, which I have sold to Joseph Crane for a house lot, at the foot of Penn’s Hill, and for which he paid me.— I planted two Rows of Nursery Red Apple seeds in Western beds 4 and 5— I wrote Letters to my Son John, and to Mrs Sary Findley, at Portsmouth, Virginia, at whose house J. Q. A. Boyd lately died— I answered also the note of Alderman Henry J. Oliver, Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements for the Services in honour of the Memory of James Monroe, informing me that Thursday the 25th at 4. in the afternoon is the time fixed for the ceremonies— And I received a Letter from Matthew St. Clair Clarke with a specimen of the reprint of Public Documents, now in process of Execution.
14. IV. Sunday.

John Kirke came in from Boston, early this morning with a Letter from my Son Charles, announcing the birth of his daughter at 3. O’Clock yesterday afternoon, about an hour before my wife reached his house.— The labour had been so expeditious that there was not time to give notice of it here— I heard Mr Capen of South-Boston, in the morning from Hosea 14.9. “Who is wise, and he shall understand these things? prudent, and he shall know them? for the ways of the Lord are right, and the just shall walk in them; but the transgressors will fall therein”— And in the afternoon, from Luke 12.57. “Yea, and why even of yourselves judge ye not what is right?” Mr Capen’s discourses are sensible, but not very impressive— I answered a Letter from Mr Ibrahim Bartlett, informing me that I had been elected an honorary member of the Norfolk Association of Teachers, and I enclosed to my Son John a Letter from his brother Charles advising him of the birth of his daughter; an event which has filled my heart with gratulation, and with anxious hopes and fears— Nor shall it pass without fervent and humble prayer to him with whom are the issues of life— In the Evening I walked to my brother’s.
15. IV. Monday.

Finished my version of the 11th. Psalm— The heat of the day was extremely oppressive. Bathed and swam from wharf to wharf with Isaac H. Adams.— Transplanted a young Cherry tree, from the road into my Nursery and planted a Row of Nursery red Apple-seeds and of Catherine Pear Cores in my Nursery beds.— About the middle of June, I planted a row of thimble berry and a row of blackberry seeds in the book-box fronting my chamber window— I saw this day, that three or four plants from them are coming up— These experiments together with those of my Strawberries in the Earthen pot,
have demonstrated that the seeds of these berries, sown when ripe vegetate the same Season, in a space between six weeks and two Months from the time of sowing. It is remarkable that I have never been able to abstain in this information, either from books on horticulture, or from conversation with cultivators— Strawberries are here universally transplanted— I have never met with any person who raised them from the seed— Blackberries and thimbleberries are wild plants scarcely ever raised in Gardens, and which perhaps have never been raised from seeds— The success of my experiment requires at least one Summer more, to ascertain what sort of fruit my vines will produce
16. IV. Tuesday.

Began my version of the 12th. Psalm— I received Letters from Chief Justice Marshall and Judge Baldwin, of the Supreme Court of the United States, acknowledging the receipt of copies of my fourth of July Oration, and expressing approbation of its contents— It has already roused critics in multitudes, and of all parties. I had also a Letter from Miles Farmer One from Joseph Blunt at New-York, urging me for the chapter for his Annual Register, which I immediately answered; and one from my Son Charles, upon which I determined to go immediately into Boston— Deacon Spear and Mr Carr were here, and I agreed with them about the fencing of my Cherry tree lot of Saltmarsh land— I went into Boston with John Kirk— Called at his office and afterwards at his house— Saw his wife and child who are both as well as could be hoped at this time. Met Mrs. Edward Brooks on a visit at his house— I called at Lord and Holbrook’s, and had conversation with Mr Lord, respecting the republication in several Newspapers of my 4th. of July Oration, by an infringement of the copy right. Many thousand copies of it have been thus disseminated, but Mr Lord did not appear disposed to go to Law, for the vindication of his right. I dissuaded him from it; and advised him rather to ask compensation from the Trespassers, as professional brethren; interested themselves in the protection of copy-rights. He said he would write to them and request them to advertise some of the books which he has upon Sale, particularly William Sullivan’s Moral Class book, just published and of which he shewed me a Copy— I told him I had a Manuscript which I should perhaps bring to him; to ascertain whether he would publish it and upon what terms— I wished him to read it himself, and place it for the perusal of some person in whose literary taste and judgment he should have entire confidence, but without informing him from whom it came; and after consulting him to determine whether he would publish and upon what terms— He said he should recur to Mr Pierpont, the Clergyman, and I told him he could not apply to a person in whom I should more entirely confide— After dinner I went with my Son Charles and James H. Foster to the Old South Church, and there read about one fourth part of my Eulogy, which took me three quarters of an hour, and exhausted my strength so that I could proceed no further— I returned with John Kirk in the Evening to Quincy—
17. IV. Wednesday.

Finished my version of the 12th. Psalm.— The intenseness of the Summer continues— Morning visit from Mr Whitney our Minister; and in the afternoon from Mr Bailey and Joseph Morton.— They brought me a Letter from John Adams, Publisher of the Boston Press, requesting of me the copy right, of my Eulogy upon President Monroe; the proceeds to be applied to the support of that Paper— I told Mr Bailey, I should place the copy right at the disposal of the City Council of Boston, and I had understood it would go of course to the City Printer; but if it should not that I had already received another application for the printing, which left me no longer free to engage it elsewhere. Mr Morton said that it was found
difficult to sustain the Boston Press— That the expense was heavy, and the Masonic combination to suppress it so powerful that it was almost irresistible— I bathed at the wharf, and swam with Isaac H. Adams— Planted 4 whole Catherine Pears in the Nursery. Received a number of slips with buds of Pear trees, from Mr Brooks of Medford; and a Card of invitation from the Mayor and Aldermen of Boston, to attend the visitation of the Public Schools on the 24th. this day week.
18. IV. Thursday.

Began the version of the 13th. Psalm, and finished the Eulogy upon James Monroe. I have been obliged to abridge this, and have omitted much of what I wished to say— It is now so long that more than half of it must be suppressed at the Delivery; and yet I shall be much perplexed to select the part to be spoken— A much more serious inconvenience is that I have not time to write it over a second time, and it will be a performance much more crude than the 4th. of July Oration— I received Letters from Rice and Thaxter, from S. A. Foot acknowledging the receipt of a Copy of my Oration; and from J. Robertson junr. a Stranger; dated Amelia County Virginia— I answered the invitation from the Mayor and Aldermen of Boston to the visitation of the public Schools; which I declined.— Price Greenleaf was here this afternoon, and budded a number of Pear-stocks, from the Slips sent me by Mr Brooks—of the Bon Chretien, Burgomaster, Crasanne, Moor-fowl Egg, Sickel and Royal Winter— Lieutt. Thomas B. Adams junr. returned from Medford, and was here— I walked to my brothers and found him ill in bed.
19. IV. Friday.

I finished yesterday the 13th. Psalm, in two six-line Stanza’s, and this day began the 16th. in the 8 line, Stanza of the 8 and 6. measure— The heat continues excessive— I bathed at the wharf and swam with I. H. Adams, at 9. this Morning. Answered a Letter from Jonathan Elliot of Washington, upon his project for publishing a new Edition of his Collection of Treaties— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here, and mentioned that his mother proposed going to morrow on a visit to Weston, and wished his brother Isaac Hull to go with her— And as he is making out the fair Copy of my Eulogy, which it is necessary should be speedily finished, the Lieutt. offered to supply his place while he should be gone; to which I consented— I planted a number of Pear Cores and Apple Seeds in my Nursery.
20. IV. Saturday.

Bath and Swim with I. H. Adams at the wharf. His brother the Lieutenant came and took his place in copying for me, and he went this afternoon with his mother to Weston— I received this morning a Letter from my Son John—one from my niece De Wint which I answered; and several from a crazy man, at New York, by the name of Rosewell Saltonstall upon Astronomy.— Mrs De Wint gave to Lieutt. T B. Adams on his late visit to Cedar grove, a Portrait of me in Crayons, done by a German named Schmidt at the Hague in 1783. when I was 16 years old— I gave it afterwards to my Sister, from whom it descended to her daughter— Mrs De Wint seems now to regret that she has given it away—and asks me to give her a Portrait of myself— Towards Evening I went with Lieutt. T. B. Adams to the Temple, and spoke a few pages of my Eulogy, till the darkness intercepted my Discourse— I then walked to my brothers and found him better than last Evening.— John Kirk came out from Boston this Evening and brought me a Note from my wife— She sends the Carriage for me to go in on Monday, and asks me to take in Mrs Nowlan, and Johns child Louisa with me.— The Vice-President of the United States, John C. Calhoun—has published a Letter containing his Sentiments on the doctrine of Nullification; about half of which came in one of the Newspapers received this Morning— He is much embarrassed what to say.
21. V. Sunday— Sun rose 5:14—

Heard Mr Green of Cambridge from Romans 12.2. “And be not conformed to this world; but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect will of God”— And in the afternoon from Acts 8.30. “Understandest thou what thou readest”— Lieutenant Adams and his brother dined with us. I answered a Letter from Stephen Bates making enquiries concerning a Letter from my father in answer to an Address from the Grand Lodge of Massachusetts in 1798— A man by the name of Sheppard on the 24th of June last delivered an Address to the Masonic Lodge at Wiscasset, which is published as a Defence of Masonry. He adduces this Letter of my father as a testimonial to the excellence of the order— Bates is reviewing it in the Boston Press, and enquires what I know concerning it. Sheppard in his notes is personally abusive upon me, without noticing this in my answer to Bates I have shewn the absurdity of an appeal to my father who never was a mason as authority in favour of the Institution— I have authorised Bates to publish my Letter if he pleases— I spent the Evening with T. B. Adams junr at T. Greenleaf’s— Dr Woodward was there. Mr Greenleaf shewed me several chesnut trees which he is raising in his Garden—from 5 to 8 years old. Also numerous varieties of Pear Trees; and clusters of Isabella grapes, prodigiously abundant.
22. IV. Monday— Saw Sirius—first time this Season.

Finished the version of the 16th Psalm yesterday and this morning began upon the 17th.— The heat of the weather continues so oppressive that I determined not to go in to Boston till the day when I am to deliver the Eulogy. Mrs Nowlan went in and took the child Louisa with her— I bathed at the wharf and swam alone. Isaac H. Adams and his mother returned from their visit to Weston and Medford— This afternoon Mr. Henry Holton Fuller, and Doctor Gamaliel Bradford members of the Φ.Β.Κ Society came and informed me that many members of the Institution not present at the late Meetings, had been much dissatisfied with the Article of the New Constitution, altering the mode of Election altering the requisite of a unanimous vote to a majority of three fourths— That several of them had determined to propose a reconsideration and repeal of that Article at the annual meeting the day after Commencement. That they wished to write a circular Letter inviting the attendance of all the members, and were desirous that I should sign it.— I was very much surprized at this application; after four days of hard debate in which I had not been sustained by a single voice, and had been repeatedly outvoted, I had given up the cause as perfectly desperate and fully acquiesced in the change which I heartily disapproved— I told these Gentlemen that I would attend at the annual Meeting, and would vote for the reconsideration and repeal; but that I must decline signing the circular invitation as it would have in me the appearance of an obstinate perseverance in my own spurious against the declared sense of the majority of the Society—and would look also like a personal opposition to the earnest wishes of Judge Story, and of Edward Everett, for both of whom I entertained an affectionate regard and esteem— They appeared to be well satisfied, and Dr Bradford, on taking leave claimed kindred with me as a descendant from John Alden. Mr Daniel Greenleaf called and invited me to dine with him to-morrow, which I accepted— My wife returned before dinner from Boston with Mrs Pitts and Louisa—leaving Mrs Nowlan in Boston.— Mrs Adams has been spending ten days with her daughter in Law, Charles’s wife during her confinement. Mrs Nowlan is to stay with her two or three days more— She is recovering gently, and her child is healthy though small.
23. IV. Tuesday: Sirius— Moon eclipsed.

Rising as the Clock struck four, on opening the window of my writing chamber I perceived that the Moon was in eclipse, although it had commenced not more than five minutes before— At five it was about five digits eclipsed, and then went under a cloud— It set, eclipsed— There were light thundershowers through the day— I dined at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s.— Mr Thomas Greenleaf and Mr Whitney were the only company.— After I came home Dr Samuel G. Howe and Dr Fisher paid me a visit— Dr Howe was an adventurer among the Greeks during their late struggle, of which he has published an historical account— He is now going to Europe on account of an association of Subscribers, who propose the establishment of a hospital for the blind; and came to enquire if I could furnish him with information or with Letters which might aid him in his pursuit—but I have no familiar correspondents in Europe; and no knowledge of the Institutions for the blind; which I regretted, especially as Dr Howe brought me an introductory Letter from Mr Peter C. Brooks— I was engaged great part of this day, in marking off passages of my Eulogy to be omitted— Received a Letter from R. Rush—

I wrote to my Son John a Letter upon business; and a few lines to Mr Horace Binney at Philadelphia, enclosing to him a copy of my 4th. of July Oration— I went this morning to the Temple, and there read the part of the Eulogy, which I propose to deliver, and which took me two hours and a quarter— I must endeavor still to abridge— Mrs Adams was quite ill; confined almost the whole day to her bed— Mr Sprague the Senator from Maine, with his wife and Son, called this afternoon; on their return home from a visit to the County of Plymouth, where his father resides—but Mrs Adams was too unwell to see them— Alpheus Spear was here, to persuade me to put a new roof of shingles on the lower barn at the Mount Wollaston farm— I promised to go down some cool day and look at it— I put down in the Nursery the white Earthen pot, in which the Seedling Strawberries have come up— Sinking the Pot so that the edge of it is level with the ground— That the runners may pass over, and take root, to spread over the bed.— I attempted this Evening to read my Eulogy over again but found a suffusion come over my eyes which compelled me to abstain and gave me some concern for the chances of to-morrow.
25. III.30. Thursday— Boston Eulogy on James Monroe at Old South Church.

Finished my version of the 17th. Psalm—a very bad one— Wrote a Letter to Lieutt. Robert Buchanan stationed at Baton Rouge Louisiana—enclosing to him a copy of my 4th. of July Oration. My wife was very imperfectly recovered from her yesterday’s indisposition; but went with me to Boston— As we came to my Son Charles’s house I met Mr Joseph E. Sprague of Salem, who went in, and sat with me upwards of an hour conversing upon Politics— The recent Elections in Kentucky have turned out less favourably to Mr Clay than his friends had expected, and the party here who obtained for him a nomination in Legislative Caucus last winter, are somewhat discouraged at the prospects before them— Mr Sprague asked me what they should do— I answered him that as he spoke with me confidentially I would answer him in perfect confidence— By their Legislative Caucus nomination of Mr Clay for the Presidency last Winter, they had put it out of their power now to choose what they would do. He said that was altogether the act of Genl. Dearborn— I said they had further kicked and buffeted the anti masonic party, till it was impossible they should support Mr Clay, and they could not fail to lose by that operation, from 60 to 70 electoral votes— I alluded to the election of County Senators in the Legislature last May; particularly
that of a Senator for the County of Plymouth— A Jackson man, preferred to a National Republican, who had from 3 to 400 more of the votes of the People— He said that was an imposition upon the Legislature, and they had much regretted their choice when they found it out— I said it proved then that they were acting under an influence of which they were not aware— And it was Masonry— I asked him if he was a Mason; he said he was an Anti-Mason— I said I did not see then how he could support Mr Clay, who was now, the head of the united Masonic and so called National Republican party. He said Mr Clay must be withdrawn. Since the Kentucky Elections it was clear he could not succeed— He finally said he wished to bring out Mr Madison and me; which I well understood, but made upon it no remark— I said I had spoken to him with the utmost confidence, with the express understanding that what I said should be exclusively between him and me— It was upon the supposition that what he said to me had been upon his own account alone— I had never been consulted, and never desired to be consulted upon the movements of the party since the 3d. of March 1829— But that if he wished to ask my opinions for any other than himself, I was willing to give them, upon condition of knowing by whom and for whom they were asked— After he left me, I went to the Old South Church, to examine the arrangements made there for the performance. Met there Alderman Harris, and Mr M’Cleary the City Clerk— The house was dark, and I strongly apprehended that as the Night should come on I should not be able to get through with my Discourse— I went to Charles’s Office, and at one O Clock took a very light dinner at his house— The procession was to go from the State house at half past three, and I was to have walked with it, but there came on a very heavy rain, and I went with Mrs Adams and Charles in a hack— At the door of the house in getting out of the Carriage, my wife fell upon the Side-walk pavement; but was saved in falling so as to have apparently received no injury. The inner door of the Church was so faithfully kept shut that it was with difficulty I obtained admission. Mr Doane and Mr Croswell, Ministers of the Episcopal Church soon came into the Pulpit. The procession moved from the State-house at the appointed time and came through a pouring rain, entering the Church about a quarter past four— A voluntary on the organ, and the prayers of the Episcopal Service with a long occasional one composed by Mr Doane, made it full five before I began— The house was crowded to suffocation; the heat excessive—crowds of People at the Church door wrangling and fighting to get in— Trucks, Waggons and Carriages rolling over the pavement in the Streets adjoining the Church, all the Time I was speaking; and as the Sun went down it grew so dark that it was becoming impossible for me to read my Manuscript— I was forced to read so rapidly that my articulation became indistinct, and my voice and my eyes affected both by the State of the Atmosphere were constantly threatening to fail me— My situation was distressing but I pushed on— I shortened the discourse much more than I had intended, and finally overleaped ten or twelve pages at once. They lighted at last the two lamps at the sides of the Pulpit, and I got through in an hour and a half, omitting more than half of what I had written— There was constant attention in the auditory— Occasional applause in one or two instances long continued and repeated— Mr M’Cleary came up and observing that the auditory had been highly delighted asked if I would join the returning procession, which I declined— Mr Eastburn the City printer came and bespoke the printing, which I promised him he should have— As soon as the Church was thinn’d off I found my family, returned to
Charles’s house, and thence immediately with my wife and Mrs Nowlan to Quincy, where we reached home, about nine in the Evening; my heart full of gratitude for having escaped an ignominious failure— Such a variety of discouraging circumstances had occurred that my anxiety was over weaning— I was thoroughly exhausted and relieved.
26. V. Friday

Began a version of the 18th. Psalm— Deacon Spear was here this Morning, with minutes for a Record of a fence round my Cherry tree lot of Saltmarsh land. He also paid me for the standing grass on that and two other Lots; and shewed me a circular printed invitation to him to attend a Convention to be held the first of next Month at Worcester to agree upon a Candidate for Governor of the Commonwealth, the ensuing year. This is called a Jackson Convention— And the circular is signed by Ebenezer Seaver as Chairman and John Henshaw as Secretary— I asked him if he proposed to attend the Convention: he said no: it would take time and money; and he did not chuse to trouble himself for a cause in which there would be no profit to himself— He said Seaver had promised to appoint him an assistant for taking the census; and then had appointed another man—and this seems to have quite extinguished the deacon’s Jacksonism.— Mr James a member of the Common Council of Boston, came out this afternoon, with Mr Eastburn the City Printer, and brought me a Letter from Alderman Oliver, Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements enclosing the joint Resolution of the boards of Aldermen and Common Council requesting a Copy of my Eulogy for the Press— I gave Eastburn the copy; from which I had spoken, promising to send in to-morrow Morning, one sheet which I had omitted from the copy made by I. H. Adams, but which I propose to publish with the rest— Eastburn said he would send me the proof sheets from day to day— The City Council bespeak from him one thousand copies, 500 of which are to be furnished to me— In the Evening I walked to my brother’s. He and his family were at Mr Edward Miller’s where I went, and found them. Mr Charles Harrod, from New-Orleans was also there— Mrs Nicholson Mrs Miller’s Sister Played on the Piano, and sung. Mrs Adams was unwell, and suffers from her yesterday’s fall.
27. IV. Saturday.

Lieutt. T. B. Adams jr. went into Boston early this morning, and I sent by him the supplementary Sheet to the copy of my Eulogy. Mrs Boylston came with her Grandson Ward, who brought with him a Letter from Mr Richardson, the Preceptor of the Academy at Leicester where he has been preparing for the University— Ward is to be offered next week, but Mr Richardson has heard so much of the rigour of the examination, that he is apprehensive Ward may not be found thoroughly fitted; and he proposes that I should examine him myself and thinks it might be advisable that he should return to the Academy and study another year before being offered for admission. But to this neither Mrs Boylston nor Ward himself would consent— I observed it would be of no use for me to examine him, as I know not what the standard for admission was; but I promised to see and converse with President Quincy concerning it—and to attend myself at Cambridge, both on Commencement day and on the day of examination, which is the Friday after. We had also conversation upon the arrangements for residence and board at Cambridge— This afternoon Dr Phelps and Mr Odiorne came out from Boston to see me—as a Committee from the Anti-Masons of Boston. They said they had learnt with regret the positive determination of Mr Rush to decline the nomination for the Presidency of the United States, by the Anti-masonic Convention which is to assemble at Baltimore, on the 26th. of next Month— That since his refusal had been known their attention
had been drawn to me, and they came to enquire if in the event of my being nominated, by that Convention, I would accept the nomination— Dr Phelps shewed me at the same time a Letter from Pittsburg in Pennsylvania urging the expediency of ascertaining my Sentiments upon Masonry, and of proposing me to the Convention— I told them that I presumed my Sentiments on the present questions between Masons and Antimasons were sufficiently known to them, and that I had authorised Mr Bates to publish a Letter from me, which would leave no doubt of my views upon this subject on the mind of any man who should read it— I had supposed it would be published before this, and knew not why it had not been. I read the Letter to them from my own Letter-book. As to the nomination—I neither desired it—nor even the Office of President of the United States itself— I would give no pledge, and make no promise to any man or body of men, to obtain it— Nor should I feel myself called upon to decline a nomination, either by a single individual, or by any body of men— I never had asked, and never should ask the vote of any person for any Office I saw no necessity for declining any nomination, which anyone might please to make— I had had no reason to believe that the Antimasons had thought of me any where, and I regretted that Mr Rush had declined the nomination offered to him, because I believed it would have been unanimous I was very apprehensive it would not be so now; and if they should propose my name, my only intreaty was that they should not press it one instant, after ascertaining that any other name would be likely to secure a more unanimous vote— With this they declared themselves entirely satisfied and left me. Lieutt. Adams returning from Boston this Evening brought me three half sheets of proof, from Mr Eastburn.
28. Sunday IV.

Heard Mr George Whitney in the Morning from John 14.2. “In my father’s house are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you: I go to prepare a place for you. 3. and if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you unto myself; that where I am there ye may be also.”— And in the afternoon from Luke 18.12. [“]I fast twice in the week, I give tithes of all that I possess.” Louisa C. Smith, dined with us, and Mr Degrand who walked out from Boston. President Quincy, and his Son the Coll. called here after the afternoon Service; and I conversed fully with the President upon the offering of Ward N. Boylston for admission at the University— I gave him the Letter from Mr Richardson, the Preceptor of Leicester Academy— He said it was true, that they had been rigorous in their examinations beyond the usage of former times, though not quite so much so as Mr Richardson had been informed— That they wished the youths to be offered for admission, and their Instructors should be impressed with the opinion that the examination would be severe; as the tendency of that impression would be to raise the standard of Scholarship for admission.— He asked me to give Ward N. Boylston, a Letter to him, and said he would pay particular attention to him. He thought it would be best for him to lodge and board in College— Mr and Mrs Angier from Medford were here— I revised the proof sheets and sent them back by Degrand to Eastburn. I wrote a Letter to my Son John.
29. IV. Monday.

My wife who has been two or three days lame with the strain which she received in falling last Thursday from the Carriage was this day so much recovered as to be able to go on a fishing party at the Creek, this afternoon, accompanied by Isaac H. Adams— My brothers other
Sons the Lieutenant, and John Quincy, at whose School in Medford there is a variation for Commencement week were here this Evening— I answered a Letter, received last Thursday, from B. B. Hotchkin of Utica—New-York. It enclosed a pamphlet containing Mr Rush’s first and second Letters upon Masonry—and the Report of a Trial at New Berlin of a suit by the Overseers of the poor, against Harlow C. Witherell— In my Nursery I planted rows of Peach Stones, four in each bed on the Eastern Side.— Also a number of Pear Cores— Received one Proof half-sheet of the Eulogy, which I corrected.
30. IV. Tuesday.

Lieutt. Adams was here, and Mrs Adams went again upon a fishing party at the Creek— I wrote a short Letter to S. L. Gouverneur at New-York, returning to him the Papers which he had sent me some weeks since; which were 1. A Letter from John Rhea of Tennessee to James Monroe, dated in June last (a copy) copy of a Letter from Mr Gouverneur, to W. Wirt, asking his advice, whether this Letter should be shewn to Mr Monroe; who was then drawing fast to his end— Two original Letters from Mr Wirt, in answer, urging very earnestly that the Letter of Rhea should be shewn to Mr Monroe— Copy of a declaration of Mr Monroe attested by two witnesses; and solemnly denying the Truth of Rhea’s Statement— I have retained copies of Rhea’s Letter, and of Mr Monroe’s declaration contradicting it.— There is a depth of depravity in this Transaction, at which the heart sickens— A total disregard to Truth, is chargeable upon so many men of the very highest standing, in this age and Country as well as in all others; that in the estimation of the world, it seems scarcely to carry with it an imputation— But the working up of a circumstantial fabrication, by practising upon the driveling dotage of a political parasite is beyond the comprehension of an honest mind. Jackson’s excessive anxiety to rest the justification of his invasion of Florida, upon a secret, collusive and unconstitutional correspondence with Mr Monroe, can be explained only by an effort to quiet the stings of his conscience for the baseness of his ingratitude to me— Writhing under the consciousness of the return which he has made to me; for saving him from public indignation, and defending him triumphantly against the vengeance of Britain and Spain, the Impeachment of Congress, the disavowal of Mr Monroe, and the Court Martial of Calhoun and Crawford, he struggles to bring his cause before the world and before posterity upon another basis— This basis is itself as rotten as his own heart— It is that his conquest of Florida, was undertaken and accomplished, not as I had successfully contended for him, upon principles, warranted by the Laws of Nations, and consistent with the Constitution of the United States, but by a secret fraudulent concert between him and Mr Monroe, in direct violation of the Constitution, and of all its conservative principles.— To establish this he resorts to his own unprincipled Letter, which I never saw, to the recreant desperation of Crawford, and to the ravenous imbecillity of John Rhea—he has succeeded with them both—both have made themselves by impudent, unblushing falsehoods Pandars to his unnatural Passions, and to glut his revenge upon me, for benefits such as he never received from any other man he has been labouring not only to blast the good name of Mr Monroe, but to cover with infamy his own— His moral perceptions are so confused, and decomposed by his convulsive Passions, that in his eagerness to throw off his obligations to me, and to ruin the reputation of Mr Monroe, he blinds himself entirely to the inevitable recoil upon himself. It is fortunate that Mr Monroe lived and retained his faculties to make a solemn and authentic declaration of the total falsehood of John Rhea’s abominable statement.
This afternoon Joseph Blunt came in from New-York by the way of Newport, New-Bedford and Hyannis—going to Boston for a few days; to look to the publication of the next volume of his Annual Register— He urged me much for the chapter, which I had undertaken to furnish for him, and I told him the reasons which have prevented me from the accomplishment of the work hitherto, and the delay which will be un-avoidable still. He stops to pass the Night here, and told me that the National Republicans in New-York were satisfied since the result of the Elections in Kentucky, that there was no prospect of success in the Election of Mr Clay to the Presidency; and that it would be advisable to fix upon another Candidate.— He spoke of Mr Webster and Chief-Justice Marshall; and supposed, if there should be a nomination of me by the Anti-Masonic Convention at Baltimore, my name would also come before the Convention to meet there next December; of which Blunt himself is a Member I told him the Anti-masons had not until within a very few days thought of me any where; and now I apprehended it was too late— I was apprehensive that they would not agree; and that their party would fall off to different Candidates to the ruin of their Cause.
31. IV. Wednesday— Commencement. Cambridge.

Mr Blunt went into Boston with me— And Isaac Hull Adams— Blunt alighted at the Tremont-House— I went to Charles’s for a few minutes, and thence with I. H. Adams to Cambridge— Alighting at the entrance of the College-Yard, I met Commodore Hull, just from Washington— I went into the Library Chamber, where I met the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, many members of the Corporation and Overseers. President Quincy, and a number of Strangers— There was a Meeting of the Overseers, at which the honorary degrees, proposed to be conferred this day by the Corporation, were confirmed—Judge Hopkinson and Peter A. Jay to be Doctors of Laws— The procession was formed and I walked with judge Davis. The merit of the Performances was beyond the usual average— The speaking incomparably better, on the whole than I ever before heard at Cambridge— Dr Barber the Englishman who was some years since at Washington is now here, a teacher of Elocution, and his instructions have greatly improved the general style of speaking— Of the undergraduate performances the two Orations of Eames and Simmons were most remarked, with one part of a Conference by Wendell Phillips the youngest Son of my old friend and associate John Phillips— I thought however that there had been rather too great a transition from tameness to over vehemence in the delivery, and that there was a corresponding change discernible in the composition, now somewhat exceptionable for exaggerated Sentiments and startling paradoxes— I made the remark to Judge Davis at whose side I sat, but he said he thought paradox was the usual defect of Commencement compositions— The English Oration for the Master’s degree by Millard, affected me beyond expression I thought it the most beautiful and pathetic effusion that I had ever heard. The Latin Valedictory by Chapman was short, and with touches of pleasantry which closed the performances of the day with much good humour— The degrees were then conferred. Bachelors and Masters of Arts and Doctors of Medicine— Then the procession proceeded to the College dining hall, where the dinner was succeeded by the singing of the 78th. Psalm Tune, St. Martin’s— Grace was said by Mr Day the President of Middlebury College Vermont, and thanks returned by my old Classmate Dr Hezekiah Packard, whom I recognized only on enquiring who he was after he had performed that ceremony. He was
the only Classmate whom I met, in the course of the day— Among the Strangers present were Mr Berrien, late Attorney General of the United States—Joseph M. White the Delegate from Florida, Mr Legaré from Charleston South-Carolina; and others— Before leaving the Hall C. H. Warren; told me there would be a meeting of members of the Φ.Β.Κ. this Evening at Concert Hall, which I was requested to attend; which I promised to do— I then called upon Dr Waterhouse, and spent half an hour with him— His youngest daughter Mrs H. Ware with two or three children was there— I then visited President Quincy’s where a numerous company were assembled— At dusk of Evening I returned to Boston with I. H. Adams; and after a few minutes of repose, attended the Meeting at Concert Hall— About forty Members attended— I was chosen Chairman; and after observation by several members a Resolution was adopted requesting the members present to attend the Φ.Β.Κ. meeting to-morrow, and support a Resolution to repeal the Article of the New Constitution adopted at the Meeting of the 11th. instt. authorizing elections of members by three fourths of the voters present, and to restore the rule requiring unanimity for election— A vote passed requesting me to offer this Resolution; but I stated the necessity that I should be under, of attending the Boylston Prize declamations, and the consequent inability of attending the ΦΒΚ. meeting at its opening. It was finally determined that Dr Bradford should offer the Resolution, and I promised to attend the Meeting if possible before a vote should be taken— I suggested the expediency of having the proposition requesting the restoration of the old Rule, signed by the members present, but upon this most of them left the Hall, without opposing the proposal— The Meeting adjourned about nine in the Evening—and I went to Dr George Parkman’s where there was an Evening party— Governor Lincoln was there—Mr Henry Middleton—Mr White of Florida—Mr Clay of Georgia, and many more— Mr White gave me an account of an interview which he lately had with President Jackson, who expressed an extreme aversion to the publication of certain Letters from himself to Dr Bronaugh on account of their spelling. It was about eleven at Night when I came home to my Son Charles’s house, exhausted by the bustling varieties of the interval, from four in the Morning when I had risen— I found two half-sheets of proof, from Eastburn.

Day. My occupations have discomposed the regularity of my course of life, and run this Diary in arrears—twenty-five days of the Month I was swallowed up in the composition of the Eulogy; having at the same time one Stanza to produce every morning in the version of Psalms; and an average of one Letter to write every day— During the preparation of the Eulogy, I was compelled to read so much for the refreshment of my Memory and for consultation, that it necessarily varied my employment, and my crippled hand often refuses its office for writing. The arrears of my Diary make me uneasy lest I should find it impracticable to retrieve them— The time spent upon the Oration, and Eulogy has not been lost or wasted— These are to remain as long as any work of mine— In each of them a valuable immediate purpose was accomplished—by the first the gratification of my Townsmen—by the second the discharge of a debt of Friendship for myself, and of public gratitude to the Memory of Mr Monroe— Nor has it been without benefit to my own Reputation— They have both succeeded far beyond my expectations, and beyond what I had dared to hope—not to give me popularity, but to acquire respect for my character.
